node.title: What to Do This Weekend
node.description: Change your clocks, contemplate your dreams.
node.content: ["Welcome. It\u2019s that time again, the end of daylight saving. Set your clocks back before you go to sleep on Saturday. Where I live, it\u2019ll be darker earlier for the next several months. The beginning of the frigid season: seven weeks until Christmas, four-and-a-half months until spring. Get comfortable. Get cozy.", "A good question to mull this weekend: Has the pandemic changed how we dream? Covid has offered scientists who study our sleeping mindscapes \u201ca natural experiment built of collective experience,\u201d and they\u2019re making the most of it. Speaking of collective experience, perhaps you\u2019re making plans for Thanksgiving. We have some tips for hosting a gathering with unvaccinated guests and a preview of what to expect if you\u2019re traveling. (Keep this savory apple galette in mind if you\u2019re planning the menu.)", "Dexter and his \u201cdark passenger\u201d return to Showtime on Sunday, eight years since the episode that \u201coften ranks with the worst finales in TV history.\u201d Mike Hale likes the South Korean sci-fi drama \u201cDr. Brain\u201d on Apple+. Watch it, then read Choe Sang-Hun on \u201cHow South Korea Became a Cultural Juggernaut.\u201d There\u2019s \u201cColin in Black & White,\u201d a new Netflix docudrama about Colin Kaepernick\u2019s early life. Or check out three good adult-animation series about kids.", "And if you\u2019ve got a bit more time, here are four movies our critics liked this week: the rom-com \u201cMark, Mary & Some Other People\u201d; the coming-of-age drama \u201cBeans\u201d; the U.S. debut of Mia Hansen-Love\u2019s first feature, \u201cAll Is Forgiven\u201d; and \u201cSimple as Water,\u201d a documentary about Syrian families displaced by war.", "\u2014From \u201cHow the New York City Marathon Grew Up,\u201d by George A. Hirsch.", "What are you watching, reading, cooking, thinking about as we move into winter? What new discoveries are you recommending to your friends? Write to us: athome@nytimes.com. Be sure to include your full name and location and we might feature your response in a future newsletter. We\u2019re At Home and Away. We\u2019ll read every letter sent. As always, more good ideas for passing the time this weekend appear below. And I\u2019ll be back next week.", "Times subscribers can sign up here to receive this newsletter twice a week."]
